text: Your favorite aunt and uncle are
on their way to visit you, great!
But you haven’t cleaned your place
in a few days, maybe weeks?
and you realize - the place stinks.
Thank goodness for Febreze, right?
Actually, thank chemistry.
(SPLASH INTRO)

We at Reactions love talking
about our sense of smell.
Believe it or not, scientists don't fully
understand HOW we smell smells,
but here's our chemist friend
Chad Jones on what we do know:
“Volatile molecules - those are chemicals that

evaporate very easily - travel
through the air to our nose.
They enter our nose and bind to receptors.
Those receptors send messages to
our brain about the kind of chemical
that’s just found itself in our nose.
What we're not sure about is
how those receptors work.
Some say the receptors work like a
lock and key, with the molecule acting
like a key in the "lock" receptor.
Others have suggested that since each
molecule vibrates in its own special way
the receptors pick up those vibrations.”
We may not know exactly how our smell
receptors work, but we do know chemical
compounds are responsible for every smell out
there, and there are lots of them, good and bad.
We love the smell of roses, fresh
cut grass and of course, bacon.
And we hate the smell of rotten eggs,
skunks, B.O. and grimy bathrooms.
And don’t leave a comment saying “oh
I like rotten egg smell.” You’re lying.
Anyway, sometimes even the amount of
a chemical you have can affect how it smells.
Take indoles. In small amounts, this family
of compounds smell like flowers.
Ahh.
But if you get too much indole in one place
it changes from a flowery smell to a
really crappy smell. Literally.
So what do we do when we don't
want to smell something?
Opening a window to convince the foul
smelling molecules to leave is always an
option or you can try to overpower it with
something more pleasant - like a candle.
Or if you’re in middle school or
from New Jersey, Axe body spray.
You may have used Febreze
or some other deodorizer.
These products claim to neutralize
the odor instead of just mask it.
What does that even mean?

“Well, Febreze contains a type
of chemical called a cyclodextrin.
It's a cage-like molecule shaped like a funnel.

This molecule traps other
molecules inside the cage.
So, if an offending odor is present it
will be trapped in this cage, unable
to escape and get to your nose.
If they were only masked, some fragrance
would out-smell the nasties for a bit, but
over time the old smell would come back.
The cyclodextrin cage means smells really
are neutralized - taken out of action.
But here's the question:
If Febreze binds up odors so well

how is it possible to have a
scented version of Febreze?”
Quick fun fact, the medical term for the
lack of a sense of smell is called anosmia.
Hmmm.
If your minds aren’t completely blown by
all of that already, let us know your other
burning chemical questions in the comments.
If you’re really curious about smelling,
we talk more about our sense of smell
in our episode on roses.
We also talk about your dog’s sense of smell
which is waay stronger stronger than yours.
Way.
Like, subscribe, share, stop and
smell the roses – in that order.
Smell you later chemheads.
Keep the good comments coming,
and if you like what you see,
give us a thumbs up.
Smell ya later, chemheads.
